rev.comment: the program is free, even for enterprises, therefore there are no licensing costs
rev.diff:
Line 22: Line 22:
Versions earlier than 3.0.0 of VMware Player were unable to create virtual machines, requiring the user to download pre-created virtual appliances or create machines for use in Player with the full [[VMware Workstation]] product, or manually create and edit the plain text ".vmx" file that defines a virtual machine. Version 3.0.0 or later lifts this limitation, allowing users to create new virtual machines in the GUI. The differences between Workstation and Player now focus on IT and developer features including clones, multiple snapshots, and secured "virtual rights management" features, which are not available in the Player product<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vmware.com/products/player/faqs.html|title=VMware Player - Frequently Asked Questions}}</ref>.
Versions earlier than 3.0.0 of VMware Player were unable to create virtual machines, requiring the user to download pre-created virtual appliances or create machines for use in Player with the full [[VMware Workstation]] product, or manually create and edit the plain text ".vmx" file that defines a virtual machine. Version 3.0.0 or later lifts this limitation, allowing users to create new virtual machines in the GUI. The differences between Workstation and Player now focus on IT and developer features including clones, multiple snapshots, and secured "virtual rights management" features, which are not available in the Player product<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vmware.com/products/player/faqs.html|title=VMware Player - Frequently Asked Questions}}</ref>.
â
VMware Player also forms part of the [[VMware Workstation]] distribution, for the purpose of site-wide installations with client users not licensed to use the full VMware Workstation product. This means that an IT administrator could create a virtual machine using Workstation, then deploy it to many computers for execution using Player without incurring a per-workstation license for VMware{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}.
+
VMware Player also forms part of the [[VMware Workstation]] distribution, for the purpose of site-wide installations with client users not licensed to use the full VMware Workstation product. This means that an IT administrator could create a virtual machine using Workstation, then deploy it to many computers for execution using Player without incurring a per-workstation license for VMware.
